info.name: Bank Management System
info.description:
A basic system written in `Python`/`Django` to facilitate the employees of a bank manage the _day-to-day_ task, such as:

1. Registering new customers and recording their KYC (Know-Your-Customer) details.
2. Assigning bank accounts to customers, where a single account may have multiple holders and each holder may have multiple accounts.  
    Currently, there are four type of accounts available in the system:
    1. Savings
    2. Current
    3. Loan
    4. Credit
3. Recording individual transactions.  
    .  
    .  
    .  
    .  
    .  
    _et cetera_

item.name: Analytics App

request.description:
API for analysts to group `customer` objects according to the rough age-group they fall into. The age-groups are as follows:

1. 0-17 years.
2. 18-25 years.
3. 26-35 years.
4. 36-45 years.
5. 46-55 years.
6. 56-65 years.
7. 66-75 years.
8. 76-85 years.
9. 86+   years.

_All the mentioned age-ranges are INCLUSIVE of their limits._

API to let analysts find the number of `customer` entities for each defined `gender` attribute registered in the system. Currently, these are the `gender` attributes supported in the system:

1. Female
2. Male
3. Other

item.description:
This editor contains the analytics functionality of the system. Currently it has two analytics APIs which are supported by helpers in the backend:

1. Group customers by age-group.
2. Find the number of customers by gender.

_Further analytics functionality is planned for development._

item.name: Banking App

request.description:
This API allows a `teller` or `accountant` type of user to create a bank account for a customer whose KYC details are complete.

The KYC details APIs and workflows are mentioned below in the `KYC App`.

API to retrieve details of all a bank account, either via its `PrimaryKey` or to retrieve the details of all bank accounts in which a given user is a `holder`.

_Querying via both is __NOT__ supported._

item.description: This application deals with banking activities such as bank-accounts, transactions, _et cetera_ and hence, is the core application of the codebase.

item.name: KYC App

request.description:
API for tellers/accountants to register a new customer to the system.

The customer's data, along with their KYC data is inserted into the system at the same time.

### Basics

1. The `customer` field contains the personal information about the customer.
2. The `kyc` field contains the values of the documents used to prove the KYC details, such as the PAN or the EPIC ID of the customer.
3. The `kyc_documents` field contains the type of ID and Address proof provided by the customer, such as the PAN Card for the proof of identity and EPIC for the proof of address.
4. The `address` field contains the address associated with the customer and will be the address used by the bank to correspond with the customer.
    

### Note

The `kyc_documents` key would only have _what_ type of document the customer is providing as proof of their details as due to a limitation of the `json` schema used for the bodies of REST APIs, both data and files cannot be uploaded at the same time.

The actual documents of `image` type are uploaded at the `upload-documents` API down below.

request.description: API to allow tellers/accountants to search for a particular customer.

API to allow tellers/accountants to upload the document proofs of the KYC details of the customer.

This is done via a separate _PUT_ API as due to a limitation of the `json` schema used for the `body` of REST API requests, files and data cannot be sent at the same time.

item.description:
This app deals with `Know-Your-Customer` details for the clients of the bank, such as:

1. Customer's personal details (name, date of birth, gender, _et cetera_)
2. Customer's address.
3. Document proof regarding the customer's KYC details.

item.name: Ledger App

request.description: API to let tellers/accountants create a ledger entry.

request.description:
API to retrieve a ledger entry/entries.

If `id` is provided, then `from` and `to` are outright ignored.

If `user` is not provided, then the requesting user's ID is taken.

If `to` and `from` are not provided and `id` is not set either, the current date is taken for both fields.

{
    "id": "f3ab4244-4a68-47db-9274-e271f45e387f",

        "id": "7be3bb2f-9613-47fb-bb3a-071385829f92",

    "created": "2023-06-18T16:40:01.497224Z",
    "updated": "2023-06-18T17:04:16.127976Z",
    "title": "Updated Title",
    "body": "It is with great joy, that I would like to announce that the ledger update API is woking as intended.\nThe world is filled with countless experiences and each one of us may reflect and recollect the same experiences differently; but over time, we may need to append to, remove from: the perceptions we may have had of these experiences, so that we may better ourselves and our understanding of the world that we live in."
}
